newsitem.title: UK: British press hails Blair election landslide.
newsitem.headline: British press hails Blair election landslide.

text.p: British newspapers on Friday hailed Tony Blair's stunning election victory and warned the Labour Party leader he now had to prove himself in office.
The Financial Times, under the headline "Bubbly is uncorked after 18 years on ice", said the new prime minister now had a strong mandate to rule Britain.
"Mr Tony Blair today has the chance to become one of the most powerful prime ministers Britain has had this century.
"Labour's crushing defeat of the Conservatives in yesterday's general election is the strongest imaginable mandate for government.
"If Mr Blair wields it wisely and decisively, he has every chance of going on to win a second term...He has the time, now he has to show us he can use it well," the FT said.
The Times also acknowledged that the country had thrown itself decisively behind Blair.
"The people have spoken and their message is ringing. Today's sweeping victory for Labour shows more than disillusionment with with a tired and incompetent Tory (Conservative) government."
"It is a comprehensive endorsement of the changes that Tony Blair has made to his party over the past three years," The Times said.
The Daily Telegraph added: "For the first time in a quarter of a century, the public felt confident enough in Mr Blair to entrust itself once again to Labour.
"If Mr Blair can justify that trust he will make a great contribution to the political life of this country. Now that he has won, we hope that he succeeds."
The Guardian also greeted a new era in British political life.
"England arose again yesterday and without a change in the heart of England there can never be a change of government..."
"We greet Labour's election with a congratulation, a cheer, and a surge of hope that it can live up to the expectations which so many millions have placed on it."
Other papers warned Blair that campaign promises were not the same as the hard business of government.
The Daily Star said: "They face a sobering truth -- they are in the driving seat and they have to make it work."
The Daily Express added: "They will not be the first to discover that promises made in opposition do not inevitably translate smoothly into government policy."
The Daily Mirror, perhaps Labpour's most fervent supporter in the British press, said: "Now prove that you're as great as we think you are."
The Daily Mail, which had backed the Conseravtives, described their defeat at the hands of the Labour Party as "The Mayday Massacre"
